questions.neutral: Timing's good - not too busy, huh?

hobby.message: You still tuning those antique typewriters?
That camera still your favorite weapon?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Not too busy is how I prefer things now.
Quiet places suit my one odd pastime—restoring old typewriters.
Safer to keep it simple these days.
Can’t say those broadcasts made the keys any lighter.
Timing’s fine, yes. Crowds make certain hobbies difficult.
I restore pre-system typewriters. A small, stubborn habit.
Old ribbons and paper aren’t easy to come by lately.
The recent confessions stirred up neighbors—more requests for help copying things.
Sometimes I regret fixing too many machines.
You’re right, not busy is better for me.
I work on antique typewriters. Cleaning, restoring, fixing stubborn keys.
Paper’s gotten scarce since things started unraveling, but I manage.
Last week, after that broadcast, folks wanted copies made again.
Strange how old skills find their use under pressure.
A bit of nostalgia in every keystroke, really.
I like a quiet spot—gives my nerves a rest.
Been fixing and collecting old typewriters longer than I care to admit.
There’s comfort in the mechanics, even when nothing else runs on time.
Broadcast nights get people talking. Suddenly my Adler sees more use than in years.
Some neighbors slip me stories to type out, things they don’t trust to the net.
The latest wave of copying confessions... my hands ache now.
Feels odd, but sometimes a hobby keeps you relevant.
I don’t mind the lull—avoids the wrong eyes for my kind of work.
Restoring antique typewriters: a habit from when the world listened instead of logged.
I keep spools, oils, and onionskins in a locked box, just in case.
Broadcast days, like last Thursday, I become the neighborhood’s hesitant scribe.
Typed up survivor lists and quiet messages when the comms went dark.
Fingers remember more than machines ever could, even in these times.
Back when I worked for the Council, notes meant candlelight and quiet—a different kind of trust.
Now the stories on my ribbon come from those who never got logged. Strange turn, isn’t it?
hobby_answer: Yes, managed to find a ribbon. Not easy these days.
Machines like that don't need updates, only care.
Noise in the building made it tricky to work at night lately.
People keep knocking, asking for 'copies.' I keep to myself.
Still prefer paper. Less questions that way.
Got the ribbon, finally. Supplies dry up quick when people panic.
Typewriters are quieter company than crowds these days.
Used it last week when the power flickered—paper never blinks out.
A few neighbors wanted help copying down names after those confessions.
I limit what I write. Enough eyes already tracking every mark.
Still, those old keys are more reliable than broadcast feeds.
Yes, Alex, found a fresh ribbon. Black ink, classic touch.
Makes a difference—keeps the old Adler purring like it should.
Used it all night after that big Council confession aired.
Neighbors brought stories they wanted typed up, real names and dates.
Never thought the typewriter would see so many hands but mine.
Hard to say no, even knowing the risks now.
Strange comfort, mechanical work, when everything else spins out.
Got that ribbon at the last supply drop, right before the free zones started organizing.
The Adler works better than half the city's tech since the BCI glitched.
Typed out survivor lists by lamplight after those Council confessionals—neighbors trusted me.
Old paper copies passed in the stairwell, no digital traces left to hunt.
Kind of odd, seeing my old hobby serve the public, even indirectly.
Had to hide carbons, too—BCI score's not high and people are watching.
Strange, this new world. The very thing they called obsolete, now essential.
Sometimes I miss when it was just letters to myself.
Yes, finally tracked down a ribbon from a friend in the free zone. Lucky find.
Adler was my grandfather's, outlasted every digital ban the Council managed.
After the Council started confessing, neighbors lined up for help. Testimonies, lost names, all needed copying.
It felt dangerous—every name becoming evidence, every sheet another secret shared.
There’s a tension, Alex. The old machines are freedom to some, but a risk to others.
BCI picked up that I was typing more—score dropped again, no surprise there.
Back when I worked for the Council, words went straight to archives. Now, each one is untraceable.
My hobby keeps me grounded, but now it connects me to more than just memory.
Funny how the world turns—paper is resistance now, and every keystroke carries weight.
